explicatoryContent.introduction: At the most advanced level, you will engage with fundamental questions about the nature of scientific knowledge: What makes science science? How does science produce reliable knowledge about the world? How should science and society interact? These philosophical questions have practical implications for how we understand and use science in society.
keyPoints: The demarcation problem asks what distinguishes science from non-science
Philosophical debates include realism, constructivism, and intermediate positions
Values play complex roles in science - both appropriately and problematically
Science and democracy have complex relationships requiring careful navigation
Critical analysis of science communication requires multiple theoretical frameworks

vocabulary.definition: The philosophical question of what distinguishes science from non-science
The view that successful scientific theories describe real features of the world
The view that scientific knowledge is constructed through social processes rather than discovered
Values related to knowledge, such as accuracy, simplicity, and explanatory power
Social, ethical, or political values that may influence science
The view that science should be free from non-epistemic values
Science addressing issues with high stakes and high uncertainty requiring extended peer review
Specialist knowledge and skill in a particular area

analogies.analogy: Consider maps. A realist about maps might say maps accurately represent real geography - mountains exist independently of maps, and good maps correspond to real terrain. A constructivist might note that maps are created using conventions (projection, scale, what to include), and different maps serve different purposes (topographical, political, transit). The terrain exists, but how we represent it involves choices. Similarly, most philosophers of science take intermediate positions: there's a real world that constrains what we can say, but how we describe it involves human choices and conventions. Good science is both responsive to reality AND socially constructed.

sections.title: The Demarcation Problem
sections.content: What distinguishes science from non-science or pseudoscience? Karl Popper proposed falsifiability: scientific claims must be testable and potentially refutable. Critics note that actual science is more complex - scientists don't immediately abandon theories when predictions fail. Thomas Kuhn's paradigm theory suggests that what counts as 'science' is determined by scientific communities. Contemporary views often emphasise a cluster of features (methodology, peer review, replication, self-correction) rather than a single criterion. The demarcation problem remains unresolved but important for understanding what makes science distinctive.

sections.title: Realism, Constructivism, and Beyond
sections.content: Scientific realism holds that successful scientific theories describe real features of the world that exist independently of our knowledge. Anti-realism notes that our theories might be useful predictive tools without necessarily describing reality accurately. Social constructivism emphasises how scientific knowledge is produced through social processes. Most contemporary philosophers adopt nuanced positions: acknowledging both that science is socially produced AND that it is responsive to a real world that constrains what theories work. The question is not whether science is 'objective' in some pure sense, but how its social processes produce reliable knowledge.

sections.title: Values in Science
sections.content: The traditional 'value-free ideal' held that non-epistemic values (social, ethical, political) should not influence scientific conclusions. Critics argue this is neither possible nor desirable. Values influence: what questions are studied, how research is conducted, what counts as sufficient evidence, and how results are applied. Feminist and post-colonial critiques highlight how values have shaped science, sometimes problematically. Contemporary views distinguish roles for values: some influence is appropriate (choosing research priorities) while other influence is problematic (biasing interpretation to support predetermined conclusions). Transparency about values is generally considered more important than their complete elimination.

sections.title: Science and Democracy
sections.content: How should scientific expertise and democratic values be balanced? 'Technocracy' would have experts make decisions; 'democratic' approaches emphasise public participation. Most scholars argue for integration: science informs democratic deliberation without replacing it. Scientists provide evidence; citizens and representatives make value-laden decisions. Challenges include: public scientific literacy, communication of complex information, expert disagreement, and ensuring democratic legitimacy while respecting expertise. The concept of 'post-normal science' (Funtowicz & Ravetz) addresses high-stakes, high-uncertainty issues requiring 'extended peer review' involving affected stakeholders.

sections.title: Critical Analysis of Science Communication
sections.content: Science communication can be analysed through multiple frameworks. Deficit model assumes public ignorance needs filling with facts; research shows this is ineffective. Engagement models emphasise dialogue and public participation. Critical approaches examine power relations: who gets to speak for science, whose concerns are heard, how communication reinforces or challenges existing power structures. Analysis should consider: framing effects (how issues are presented), trust dynamics, the role of identity and values in interpreting information, and the institutional contexts of communication. Sophisticated analysis recognises that science communication is never neutral transmission of facts but involves choices about framing, emphasis, and context.

caseStudy.title: The COVID-19 Pandemic: Science, Policy, and Public Trust
caseStudy.scenario: The COVID-19 pandemic presented unprecedented challenges for science, science communication, and the relationship between science and policy, raising fundamental questions about expertise, trust, and democratic decision-making during crisis.
observations: Scientists developed vaccines in record time, demonstrating the power of scientific collaboration
Changing guidance (masks, transmission mechanisms) was sometimes interpreted as inconsistency rather than science updating with evidence
Different countries took different approaches to lockdowns, reflecting different values balances
Misinformation spread rapidly on social media, sometimes outpacing scientific communication
Trust in expertise varied dramatically across populations, correlating with political identity
Scientists sometimes made policy recommendations while presenting them as purely scientific conclusions

questions.question: How did the pandemic illustrate the challenge of communicating changing scientific understanding?
questions.answer: Early pandemic science was necessarily provisional - a new virus required rapid learning. Changing guidance reflected science working properly, updating as evidence emerged. But public communication often presented guidance as certain, so changes appeared as failures. This illustrates tension between the provisional nature of science and public expectation of certainty. Better framing ('based on current evidence', 'as we learn more we may update') might have helped, but time pressure and the need for clear public health messaging created genuine dilemmas.

questions.question: How were values involved in pandemic policy decisions?
questions.answer: Scientific evidence informed what was possible (how virus spreads, vaccine efficacy). But policy decisions involved values: how to balance public health against economic harm, individual liberty against collective responsibility, protecting vulnerable groups against lockdown harms. Different countries weighted these differently, resulting in different policies even with similar scientific understanding. Scientists sometimes crossed from evidence to policy recommendations without making the value judgments explicit.

questions.question: How did the pandemic illustrate issues of trust and expertise?
questions.answer: Trust in scientific expertise varied, often along political lines. Some saw expert guidance as legitimate authority; others saw it as elite imposition. Mistrust was amplified by perceived inconsistency, by experts sometimes exceeding their expertise, and by political polarisation. The pandemic showed that expertise alone doesn't guarantee public trust - trust must be earned through consistency, transparency, acknowledging uncertainty and values, and respecting democratic concerns.

questions.question: What lessons about science communication emerged from the pandemic?
questions.answer: The deficit model (just give people facts) was inadequate. Identity and values shaped interpretation of information. Pre-existing distrust was hard to overcome with evidence. Misinformation exploited genuine complexities. Effective communication needed to acknowledge uncertainty, address values explicitly, build on existing trust relationships, and engage with rather than dismiss concerns. The pandemic demonstrated the need for science communication that is honest about both what science knows and what it doesn't, and about where science ends and values begin.

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: The pandemic accelerated conversations about science, expertise, and democracy that will continue. Future challenges (climate change, AI, bioethics) will require navigating similar territory. The lessons learned - about communicating uncertainty, distinguishing evidence from values, building trust, and respecting democratic deliberation - have application far beyond public health.
caseStudy.modelAnalysis: The COVID-19 pandemic provides a rich case study for examining fundamental questions about science and society. It illustrates how rapidly science can advance under pressure, how challenging it is to communicate evolving understanding, how values inevitably enter policy decisions, and how trust is essential for translating knowledge into action. Analysis requires integrating perspectives from philosophy of science, sociology, communication studies, and political science.

remember.question: What is the demarcation problem in philosophy of science?
options: How to separate good experiments from bad ones
The question of what distinguishes science from non-science
How to draw boundaries between scientific disciplines
The problem of measuring accurately

feedback.correct: Correct! The demarcation problem asks what makes science science - what criteria distinguish it from pseudoscience and other knowledge claims.
feedback.incorrect: The demarcation problem is the philosophical question of what distinguishes science from non-science or pseudoscience.

remember.question: What is the difference between epistemic and non-epistemic values?
options: There is no difference
Epistemic values relate to knowledge (accuracy, explanatory power); non-epistemic values are social, ethical, or political
Epistemic values are older; non-epistemic are newer
Epistemic values are scientific; non-epistemic are not

feedback.correct: That's right! Epistemic values concern knowledge production (like accuracy), while non-epistemic values are broader social, ethical, or political considerations.
feedback.incorrect: Epistemic values relate to knowledge itself (accuracy, simplicity). Non-epistemic values are social, ethical, or political values that may also influence science.

understand.question: Why do most contemporary philosophers of science reject both naive realism and extreme constructivism?
options: Philosophy never reaches conclusions
Both positions capture partial truths: science is socially produced AND responsive to a real world
Only realism is correct
Only constructivism is correct

feedback.correct: Exactly! Naive realism ignores the social nature of science; extreme constructivism ignores how nature constrains our theories. Nuanced positions recognise both dimensions.
feedback.incorrect: Most philosophers adopt nuanced positions recognising that science is both socially produced AND responsive to reality that constrains which theories work.

understand.question: What does 'post-normal science' (Funtowicz & Ravetz) address?
options: Science that happens after normal science
Science addressing high-stakes, high-uncertainty issues requiring extended participation beyond traditional peer review
Science that rejects normal methods
Science done by non-scientists

feedback.correct: Correct! Post-normal science addresses issues where stakes are high, uncertainties large, values in dispute, and decisions urgent - requiring 'extended peer communities' including affected stakeholders.
feedback.incorrect: Post-normal science addresses high-stakes, high-uncertainty issues (like climate change) that require expanded participation beyond traditional scientific peer review.

apply.question: During the pandemic, some scientists advocated for strict lockdowns while others advocated for looser restrictions. Both cited scientific evidence. How should this be understood?
options: One group must have been unscientific
They may have agreed on evidence but differed on value trade-offs (health vs. economy, liberty vs. safety) that science alone cannot resolve
Science cannot address pandemics
Scientists should not discuss policy

feedback.correct: Correct! Scientists can agree on evidence while disagreeing about policy because policy involves value trade-offs that science itself cannot determine.
feedback.incorrect: Policy disagreement among scientists often reflects different value weightings rather than scientific disagreement. Science informs but doesn't determine value trade-offs.

apply.question: How would you apply the concept of 'epistemic injustice' to analyse whose knowledge counts in scientific debates?
options: Epistemic injustice is irrelevant to science

Some groups may be dismissed as knowers due to prejudice (testimonial injustice) or lack concepts to articulate their knowledge (hermeneutical injustice), leading to incomplete scientific understanding
Science automatically includes all perspectives
Only scientists have relevant knowledge

feedback.correct: Sophisticated application! Epistemic injustice (Miranda Fricker) can explain how some knowledge is excluded - as when indigenous knowledge was dismissed, or women's health concerns weren't taken seriously. This has practical implications for whose voices are heard in science.
feedback.incorrect: Epistemic injustice considers how some groups may be wrongly dismissed as knowers due to prejudice, leading to incomplete understanding.

analyse.question: The pandemic saw scientists making policy recommendations while sometimes presenting them as purely scientific conclusions. Analyse this phenomenon.
options: Scientists should never discuss policy

This illustrates the challenge of distinguishing the scientific question (what is happening) from the policy question (what should be done, which involves values). Presenting value-laden recommendations as purely scientific undermines trust when the value choices are later revealed
Scientists' policy recommendations are always scientific
Policy and science are the same thing

feedback.correct: Excellent analysis! When scientists present value-laden recommendations as purely scientific, they obscure the value choices involved. When these become apparent, trust can be damaged. Transparency about the role of values in recommendations is important.
feedback.incorrect: This reflects the challenge of distinguishing scientific evidence from policy recommendations involving values. Obscuring value choices undermines trust.

analyse.question: Analyse why the 'deficit model' of science communication proved inadequate during the pandemic.
options: The public is too ignorant to understand science
The deficit model assumes information changes behaviour, but pandemic response showed that values, identity, trust, and social context mediate how people interpret scientific information
Science communication worked perfectly
The deficit model is always correct

feedback.correct: Correct! The pandemic showed that simply providing information ('filling the deficit') doesn't change behaviour. How people interpret information depends on values, identity, trusted sources, and social context. Effective communication must engage with these factors.
feedback.incorrect: The deficit model failed because how people interpret information depends on values, identity, and trust - not just the information itself.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that science should be 'value-free.'
options: Science is completely value-free

While problematic value influences should be minimised, eliminating values entirely is neither possible nor desirable. Values appropriately influence research priorities and ethically inform practice. The goal should be transparency about values and preventing values from distorting evidence interpretation
Values are always beneficial in science
Only epistemic values matter

feedback.correct: Nuanced evaluation! Contemporary philosophy of science recognises that complete value-freedom is impossible and some value influences are appropriate. The key is transparency about values and preventing them from distorting evidence interpretation.
feedback.incorrect: Complete value-freedom is neither possible nor entirely desirable. Values appropriately influence some aspects of science. Transparency is key.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the tension between 'following the science' and democratic decision-making.
options: Science should make all decisions

There is genuine tension: science provides essential evidence, but democratic legitimacy requires public participation in value-laden decisions. Good policy integrates scientific evidence with democratic deliberation about values and priorities
Democracy should ignore science
There is no tension

feedback.correct: Well-balanced evaluation! This tension is real and important. Science informs but doesn't replace democratic decision-making. The challenge is integrating expertise with democratic participation.
feedback.incorrect: There is genuine tension between expertise and democracy. Neither 'technocracy' nor ignoring expertise is acceptable; integration is needed.

create.question: Propose principles for science communication that address philosophical insights about the nature of science.
options: Simply explain facts clearly

Acknowledge that scientific knowledge is both robust and provisional; distinguish well-established conclusions from ongoing research; be transparent about uncertainty and values; engage with audience concerns rather than dismissing them; recognise that trust is essential and earned through transparency and respect
Only communicate certainties
Avoid all discussion of uncertainty

feedback.correct: Excellent principles! These integrate philosophical understanding (provisionality, role of values) with practical communication strategies (transparency, engagement, trust-building).
feedback.incorrect: Philosophically-informed communication acknowledges provisionality, distinguishes certainties from open questions, is transparent about uncertainty and values, and builds trust through engagement.

create.question: How would you redesign science advice to governments to address lessons from the pandemic?
options: Give scientists complete authority

Create transparent processes that: distinguish scientific evidence from policy recommendations; acknowledge uncertainty and what is unknown; include diverse expertise; make value choices explicit; enable democratic debate about value trade-offs; build pre-existing trust through ongoing engagement
Exclude scientists from policy discussions
Keep all science advice secret

feedback.correct: Thoughtful design! This addresses key issues: transparency, distinguishing evidence from values, acknowledging uncertainty, ensuring democratic legitimacy while respecting expertise.
feedback.incorrect: Better science advice would distinguish evidence from recommendations, acknowledge uncertainty, be transparent about values, and enable democratic deliberation.

unistructural.question: Explain the difference between scientific realism and constructivism in philosophy of science.
unistructural.modelAnswer: Scientific realism is the view that successful scientific theories describe real features of the world that exist independently of our knowledge. On this view, science progressively discovers truths about nature. Constructivism is the view that scientific knowledge is constructed through social processes - it emphasises how scientific facts are produced rather than discovered. On this view, science is a human activity shaped by social factors. Most contemporary philosophers adopt intermediate positions, acknowledging that science is both socially produced (constructivist insight) AND responsive to a real world that constrains what theories work (realist insight). The debate concerns how much scientific theories correspond to reality versus how much they reflect human choices and conventions.

rubric.full: Clearly explains both positions and notes that most philosophers adopt intermediate views
rubric.partial: Explains both positions but doesn't address nuanced contemporary views
rubric.minimal: Provides partial explanation of one or both positions

multistructural.question: Describe three different roles that values play in science, and explain which roles are generally considered appropriate versus problematic.
multistructural.modelAnswer: 1. Choosing research priorities: Values legitimately influence what scientists study. Society's values about health, environment, or technology direct research funding and attention. This is generally considered appropriate - research should serve societal goals. 2. Methodological standards: Values influence what counts as sufficient evidence for conclusions. This involves epistemic values (preferring simpler explanations) but also decisions about acceptable risk of error. These decisions involve judgments that aren't purely logical. This is a grey area - some value influence may be unavoidable and appropriate if transparent. 3. Interpretation of evidence: Values could bias how evidence is interpreted - seeing what one wants to see. Scientists may unconsciously interpret ambiguous data in ways that confirm their prior beliefs or serve their interests. This is generally considered problematic - evidence interpretation should be as objective as possible. The key distinction is whether values influence the scientific process in ways that are transparent and don't distort evidence, versus hidden biases that cause scientists to misrepresent what the evidence shows.

rubric.full: Describes three roles with clear explanation of which are appropriate versus problematic and why
rubric.partial: Describes three roles but evaluation of appropriateness is incomplete
rubric.minimal: Describes some value influences without clear evaluation

relational.question: Analyse how the COVID-19 pandemic revealed tensions between scientific expertise and democratic decision-making. Propose principles for navigating these tensions.
relational.modelAnswer: The pandemic revealed fundamental tensions: Tension between expertise and democracy: Public health measures were often presented as 'following the science,' but they involved value trade-offs (health vs. economy, individual liberty vs. collective safety) that are properly democratic questions. Experts sometimes exceeded their expertise in making policy recommendations. Tension between provisionality and action: Science updates as evidence emerges, but public health required decisive action. Changing guidance appeared as inconsistency to the public. Tension between uniformity and pluralism: Different communities had different values and circumstances, but pandemic response often imposed uniform measures. Tension between trust and scepticism: Appropriate trust in expertise was challenged by historical reasons for distrust in some communities. Principles for navigation: 1. Distinguish clearly between scientific evidence (what we know) and policy recommendations (what we should do). Make explicit where scientific advice ends and value judgments begin. 2. Embrace uncertainty transparently. Communicate what is known, unknown, and how understanding may change. 3. Deliberate values democratically. Experts inform but don't replace democratic discussion of trade-offs. 4. Respect diverse values and circumstances. One-size-fits-all approaches may not be appropriate. 5. Build trust through transparency and acknowledging limitations. Trust is essential and must be earned. 6. Include diverse voices. Whose knowledge counts? Whose concerns are heard? Extended participation improves both legitimacy and quality.

rubric.full: Provides sophisticated analysis of multiple tensions and proposes well-reasoned principles addressing each
rubric.partial: Analyses some tensions with principles but depth is limited in some areas
rubric.minimal: Addresses the topic but analysis of tensions or proposed principles lack depth

extendedAbstract.question: Drawing on philosophy of science, analyse the challenge of maintaining public trust in science while being honest about its limitations and provisionality. How might science communication and institutions be reformed to address this challenge?
extendedAbstract.modelAnswer: The core paradox: Science's provisionality (updating with evidence) is a strength for producing reliable knowledge, but creates vulnerabilities for public trust when presented as inconsistency. Being honest about limitations might seem to undermine authority, yet hiding limitations eventually damages trust more when they're revealed. Philosophical foundations: From philosophy of science, we understand that: science is both socially constructed AND reality-constrained; consensus is reliable even while individual findings may be revised; uncertainty is inherent and appropriate caution, not weakness; values inevitably enter science at various points. Current problems: The 'deficit model' assumes public ignorance causes distrust - but research shows values and identity matter more. Scientists sometimes overclaim certainty, then appear unreliable when knowledge updates. The authority of science is sometimes claimed for value positions that aren't purely scientific. Distrust often has legitimate historical roots (communities have been harmed by science). Reforms to science communication: 1. Embrace epistemic humility: Be clear about what is well-established, what is emerging, and what remains unknown. Use calibrated language matching certainty to evidence. 2. Distinguish knowledge from application: Clearly separate 'what science tells us' from 'what we should do about it,' acknowledging the latter involves values. 3. Address values transparently: Acknowledge that choosing research priorities and interpreting evidence involves values. Be explicit about whose values are represented. 4. Engage rather than inform: Move beyond the deficit model to genuine dialogue. Address concerns rather than dismissing them. 5. Acknowledge historical harms: Recognise that distrust sometimes has legitimate historical roots. Trust must be rebuilt, not simply demanded. Institutional reforms: 1. Diverse representation: Ensure scientific institutions reflect diverse communities. This affects what questions are asked and whose concerns are taken seriously. 2. Incentive alignment: Current incentives (publishing novel findings) can encourage overselling. Reward replication, null findings, and public engagement. 3. Independent science journalism: Support media that can interpret science accurately for the public, rather than sensationalising. 4. Pre-bunking misinformation: Proactively explain how science works and common misinformation tactics before crises occur. 5. Extended peer review: For high-stakes issues, include affected stakeholders in evaluating evidence and its implications (as per post-normal science). Limitations and tensions: There are genuine tensions that cannot be fully resolved. Communicating uncertainty while maintaining public health messaging is genuinely difficult. Incremental improvement in how science is communicated and institutionalised can strengthen public trust while maintaining honesty about science's nature.
